title: 6 Little known energy discounts that could knock hundreds off your winter bills
text:

More than a million pensioners are expected to miss out on a £140 discount on their energy bills this winter, worrying figures show.

A lack of awareness means households will lose out on the Warm Home Discount - which requires participating domestic energy suppliers to provide support to those who are in, or at risk of, fuel poverty.

According to figures from Ofgem and the Department for Work and Pensions, last year 1,214,571 customers received the rebate.

However, 1,343,450 over 65-year-olds were eligible for the discount, meaning that over 100,000 people missed out.

The Warm Home Discount is available to people who are in receipt of the Guarantee Credit element of Pension Credit, who have reached the state pension age and live on a weekly income of less than £167.25 for a single person or £255.25 for a couple.

It comes as figures by comparison website Comparethemarket show more than one in five over 65-year-olds rationed their energy usage last winter in order to afford their energy bills, equating to 2.7 million people nationwide.

So what can you do to save on your bills over the coldest season?

Well, you have six options - and we've run through these with the team at auto-switching service Switchcraft, below.

Not eligible, perhaps it's time you switched to a cheaper supplier instead.

(Image: Getty)

1. Warm Home Discount

What is it? The Warm Home Discount is a support scheme aimed at households who may struggle to pay their energy bills.

The scheme was introduced by Government on April 1, 2011 and will run until 2021.

It's a one-off £140 discount on your energy bill over winter - but instead of being paid directly to you, it's automatically deducted from your bill over the winter months (between September and March).

You may also receive it as an energy rebate - all payments for last winter were paid by March 31, 2018. It's usually paid by Spring the following year, ie April 2020 for this coming winter.

How much? £140

Available in: England, Scotland, Wales

Who can claim? Low-income households; those on qualifying benefits

Deadline to apply: Applications open until March 31, 2021

Find out more on the Warm Home Discount, here.

2. Cold Weather Payments

(Image: Getty)

What is it? Cold Weather Payments are paid out by the Government during times of especially freezing weather.

The money goes to people on low incomes who receive a qualifying benefit, such as pension credit or certain employment benefits, when temperatures sink to below 0°C in the area they live in.

Payments are triggered by data collected by the Met Office from 94 weather stations around Britain.

The scheme runs each year from November 1 to March 31.

If you do qualify, you'll get a £25 a week payment for every seven-day spell of cold weather you experience.

The money is paid to the recipient within 14 days.

How much? £25 a week

Available in: England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland

Who can claim? Low-income households; qualifying benefits when temperature falls to 0°c or below for seven days in a row.

Deadline to apply: October 1, 2019 - March 31, 2020

Find out more on Cold Weather Payments, here.

3. Winter Fuel Payment

What is it? The winter fuel allowance is a scheme designed to support vulnerable people over the colder months.

It was introduced around 20 years ago to help older people who were being forced to choose between eating and heating - it's a universal entitlement, and automatically paid to anyone who qualifies over the age of 64.

The scheme covers the period between November and December each year - those eligible should get their money by 14 January in the winter they're claiming it. It's paid directly into your bank account.

How much? £100-£300

Available in: England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland

Who can claim? Anyone born before April 5, 1954

Deadline to apply: Applications open until March 31, 2020

Find out more on the Winter Fuel Payment, here.

4. Energy Company Obligation Three

What is it? The Energy Company Obligation (ECO) is an initiative that energy suppliers must follow to help households cut their energy bills and reduce carbon emissions by installing energy-saving measures.

By last September, the Government said it had delivered over 2.4million measures in around 1.9million homes.

The idea is to help reduced bills in the long term for low income, vulnerable and fuel poor households.

It also includes supporting households that have a broken heating system by allowing the equivalent of 35,000 broken heating systems to be replaced per year.

How much? £1,000+ off home improvements

Available in: England, Scotland, Wales

Who can claim? Supplier dependent and based on your home's efficiency rating

Deadline to apply: Applications open until 31/03/22

Find out more here.

5. Nest Fuel Poverty

What is it? Welsh Government Warm Homes, which includes the Arbed and Nest schemes, provides funding for energy efficiency improvements to low income households and those living in deprived communities across Wales.

Homes are assessed individually to determine which energy efficiency measures are needed and will be most effective (ie insulation, draught proofing and boiler replacement). The energy saving measures will be implemented by British Gas who is the Nest partner for the scheme.

All households are able to receive a minimum 40% grant towards the cost of installing loft and/or cavity wall insulation. Some homes can receive a 100% grant.

How much? £408 a year (on average)

Available in: Wales

Who can claim? Means tested - based on health conditions. The domestic property must have an energy efficiency rating of F or G (poor energy efficiency).

Find out more on the Next Fuel Poverty scheme, here.

6. Warmer Homes Scotland

What is it? Warmer Homes Scotland is designed to help vulnerable people make their homes warmer and more comfortable by installing a range of energy-saving measures.

Last year the Government said over 14,000 households had received energy-saving changes through the scheme - effectively reducing their bills. Most have received measures valued at over £4,000.

As well as a warmer house, experts say those who have qualified for the scheme have saved an average of £326 a year on their energy bills.

How much? £350 a year (on average)

Available in: Scotland

Who can claim? Homeowners and private sector tenants struggling to heat their home, who have lived in their property for at least 12 months, and who meet the qualifying criteria.

Find out more on Warmer Homes Scotland, here.

"As the mercury drops, we can be certain that one thing will rise," Alex Dickson at Switchcraft said.

"Long showers, cranked thermostats and electric blankets beckon higher energy-bills. Some consumers might not be aware that the typical UK household spends more than half of its total billings on heating – even before things get chilly.

"And if you’re one of the 15million energy customers sitting on a default energy tariff this winter, expect to be forking out hundreds in unnecessary payments."

"Forget the price-cap, forget extra blankets and forget hotties. If your home is on a 'default' or 'standard variable' tariff this winter, the single biggest contributor to energy bills won’t be heating, it’ll be your supplier.

"That’s why it’s so important to shop around for an energy deal."

description: From the Warm Home Discount to Cold Weather Payments for when the big chill hits, here's what you need to know
